abstract.text: The base class for objects that are part of a 3D asset, including meshes, cameras, and lights.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: When you load content from an asset file using the
class, Model I/O creates instances of the
subclasses
, and
. For asset formats that describe a collection of meshes, cameras, and lights organized in a hierarchy of spatial transforms, Model I/O also creates instances of the
class itself to describe the transform nodes that organize the asset’s visual content. Similarly, you use the
class and its subclasses when creating an object graph to be exported as an asset file using  the
class.
Model I/O allows you to customize the content and relationships in an object graph with
components
. For each aspect of an object’s functionality, you use a component protocol (extending the
protocol) to define functionality and a class adopting that protocol to implement it. Then, you can use the
and
methods to associate those objects with any instance of the
class or of one of its subclasses. For example, you might define a protocol to add gameplay-related information such as scripting triggers to certain meshes, lights, or cameras in a scene.
Model I/O itself uses this mechanism to handle object hierarchies and spatial transforms: The methods listed in
use the
protocol to model hierarchic relationships between objects in an asset, and the methods listed in
use the

protocol to model coordinate space relationships. To add support for an asset file format or object graph that uses other ways to store or compute these relationships, you can use your own classes that adopt these protocols.

abstract.text: Import, export, and manipulate 3D models using a common infrastructure that integrates MetalKit, GLKit, and SceneKit.
An indexed container for 3D objects and associated information, such as transform hierarchies, meshes, cameras, and lights.
The minimal volume containing an object, used by the
method.
A point of view for rendering a 3D scene, along with a set of parameters describing an intended appearance for rendering.
The base protocol for extensible file format support in Model I/O.
The abstract superclass for objects that describe light sources in a scene.
A container for vertex buffer data to be used in rendering a 3D object.
The common interface for Model I/O objects that expose a human-readable name.
The base class for objects that are part of a 3D asset, including meshes, cameras, and lights.
Adds a child object to this object, creating a container for the object’s children if necessary.
Returns the child object at the specified path.
Returns the minimum region entirely enclosing the object’s contents at the specified time sample.
A component that manages this object’s collection of children.
Returns the object’s component for the specified protocol.
Executes the specified block using each object in this object’s child hierarchy.
A Boolean value indicating whether this object should be used in rendering.
The primary object, if applicable, of which this object is an instance.
The parent object that contains this object.
A path that identifies the object in an asset’s object hierarchy using object names.
Associates a component with the object for the specified protocol.
A component that manages this object’s spatial transform and its changes over time.
The general interface for classes that can act as containers in an object hierarchy.
A container for index buffer data and material information to be used in rendering all or part of a 3D object.
A description of how a submesh’s index buffer data is arranged and how that arrangement should be used to produce the submesh’s intended 3D shape.
A description of the local coordinate space transformations for a 3D object.
The general interface for classes that manage local coordinate space transforms for 3D objects
A model of a 3D object’s solid volume as a collection of

inlineContent.text: voxels

abstract.text: , or cubic units.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
